subject: statistics
title: Potential Outcomes and Confounding
contentHtml:
In causal inference, potential outcomes refer to the possible outcomes of an intervention or treatment. For instance, in a medical trial, we might consider the potential outcomes for patients who receive a new medication versus those who do not.

Confounding occurs when a third variable affects both the treatment and the outcome, making it difficult to isolate the effect of the treatment.
name: Potential Outcomes" },
problemHtml: Suppose we want to study the effect of a new exercise program on weight loss. We randomly assign participants to either an exercise group or a control group.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Define potential outcomes for each participant", "mathHtml": "\[Y_i(y) = \begin{cases} Y_i(0) & \text{if } Z_i = 0 \\ Y_i(1) & \text{if } Z_i = 1\end{cases}\]", "explanation": "We consider the potential weight loss for each participant in both groups"} ],
intuition: Understanding potential outcomes and confounding is crucial for identifying causal relationships between variables.
